Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the Purpose of the Conspicuousness Coloration and its Relationship with Self-Synthesized Toxins in Australian Frogs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Warning coloration (conspicuous coloration coupled with a negative consequence such as toxins) is a common defensive strategy throughout the animal kingdom. The best examples of warning coloration in vertebrates come from amphibians. Despite how common warning coloration is, little is understood about how it evolves and diversifies. Traditional evolutionary theory dictates that predator cognition should constrain diversification of warning signals, but a number of species exhibit a wide variety of signals both within and among populations. While collaborating with Dr. Michael Mahony (University of Newcastle) and Dr. Stephen Donnellan (University of Adelaide) in eastern Australia, this project will examine the evolution and diversification of conspicuous coloration in a group of small, toxic frogs (Pseudophryne). This project will elucidate 1) the purpose of conspicuousness coloration in this genus and 2) how predators can influence diversification of color signal in a group of Australian endemic frogs.

By using clay models to mimic phenotypes found in Pseudophryne, this project aims to understand if 1) dorsal coloration acts as warning coloration, 2) ventral coloration acts as warning coloration or disruptive coloration, and 3) how predators generalize to color signals based on past experiences with local forms. Clay models will be placed on transects in areas where Pseudophryne are found to allow predators accustomed to local forms to prey upon models. Models will be placed either on natural or white backgrounds to determine if signals are warning coloration or not. Models will be collected and scored for type of predator attack based on dentition left in the plasticine clay. This will allow for the determination for what predators may be influencing color evolution in this group as well as how they react to novel signals. Pseudophryne are the only group of frogs that synthesize their own alkaloid toxins, which are common in other aposematic animals, but derived by diet. This research has implications for understanding how mode of toxin acquisition may influence the evolution of warning signals. Findings of this research will be applicable to a number of aposematic species around the world.

Does Color Matter? Effects of Toxin Biosynthesis on the Evolution of Polytypism and Aposematism in Australian Brood Frogs (genus Pseudophryne)

 

            Aposematism, or warning coloration, is a ubiquitous defensive strategy throughout the animal kingdom being represented in nearly all major animal taxa. The main features of aposematism is a bright or conspicuous color signal that is often coupled with some negative consequence, most often in the form of distasteful chemical compounds. Despite its ubiquity, the origins and diversification of aposematism are still hotly debated and largely in dispute, if not completely unknown, in the scientific community.

            Some of the confusion surround the diversification of aposematic signaling have to do with the fact that some color signals, while on the surface may seem conspicuous to the human eye, are not necessarily conspicuous to predators. One such group that exhibits such unclear signaling are the frogs in the genus Pseudophryne, the Australian Brood Frogs. These frogs vary considerably in dorsal color signal with some species being completely brown to the other extreme where the Corroboree Frogs (P. corroboree and P. pengilleyi) have bright yellow-and-black striping. Despite this variation within and among species, no research has been conducted to examine the purpose of this coloration and if it is aposematic in function. These frogs are toxic, so it stands to reason that these color signals may be a warning to predators. Further complicating matters for these frogs, all species have very conspicuous white-and-black blotching on their venter. This conspicuous blotching could be a signal to predators who do not have color vision (i.e., mammals).

            To examine this, 1395 plasticine clay models were created in eight different phenotypes which represented five dorsal phenotypes, the blotchy black-and-white ventral phenotype, a solid black frog, and a solid white frog, the latter three representing ventral phenotypes. These models were placed in Watagans National Park in New South Wales, Australia and left to sit for seven days so that predators could attack them. After the seven days, the models were collected, and then scored for what types of predators attacked the models with the main focus being on either avian predators, which see well in color vision, or mammalian predators that can pick up on high-contrast signals. Of the 1395 models recovered, 35 were attacked unambiguously by birds and 39 were attacked unambiguously by mammals. While no single phenotype was attacked more than any other for either type of predator, when comparing all of the ventral phenotypes to all of the dorsal phenotypes, we do see differences in attack rates for birds, but not mammals. Birds were significantly more likely to attack ventral phenotypes over the dorsal phenotypes. There was no difference for mammals.
